Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Flood Risk Projections with Climatic Variation and Human-Induced Shifts in Hydrologic Response
Award.AbstractNarration:
A large portion of the U.S. population, infrastructure, and industry is located in flood prone areas; however, structural and nonstructural strategies [e.g., the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP)] used to reduce the economic, social, and environmental impacts of floods continue to be based on static estimates of flood risk despite the documented influence of urbanization and climatic variation on flood peaks. Thus, the current challenge is to create a statistical framework to project future flood risk that accounts for natural climate variability, potential climate change, and impending land use changes. In view of this need, the objectives of this research are: to develop and test methods that extend traditional statistical flood risk models to project future flood risk, and to determine the relative impacts of climatic variation and anthropogenic activities on flood risk under future scenarios of climate change, land use, and emissions in the Northeastern United States. This study region was chosen because it includes a range of flood generating mechanisms, and connections between flood peaks and oceanic-atmospheric patterns have been identified therein. These research objectives will be achieved through a combination of observation-based statistical models that use extant data and physically-based hydrologic models that simulate flood series under future scenarios.

The benefits to society from this project will flow from the creation of a physical-causal based statistical framework for flood risk projection. This framework, combined with knowledge of the relative impacts of climatic variation and anthropogenic activities on flood risk under future scenarios, will provide the groundwork for new advances in water resources management. The framework could be used to develop a stochastic NFIP, and would facilitate impact assessments, such as analysis of the implications associated with land use planning and management scenarios. In addition, this project will: increase K-12 student awareness to the consequences of human activities on hydrologic processes, increase K-12 student interest in science and engineering careers, and increase undergraduate student interest to pursue advanced science and engineering degrees. These outcomes will be accomplished through the integration of research and educational student experiences at high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. In particular, field trips for area ninth grade students will be held throughout the duration of the project, an interactive web module and corresponding lesson plan will be developed for use beyond completion of this project, graduate and undergraduate students will participate in outreach activities, and research themes will be integrated into undergraduate water resources coursework. Special efforts toward recruiting and retaining women will be made through outreach activities and positive mentoring of summer undergraduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we developed an approach to project future flood risk that accounts for natural climate variability, potential climate change, and impending land use changes. The methodology combines physically-based hydrologic models that simulate flood series under future scenarios and observation-based statistical models that provide the associated flood risk distribution. The modeling framework also allows for assessment of the relative impacts of climatic variation and changes in anthropogenic activities and land cover on flood risk.

At a regional level, spanning multiple states in the Northeast and Upper Midwest US, a total of 378 sites were considered. Specific outcomes of this research at this large scale include identification of forms of nonstationarity in flood series at both impaired and moderately impaired sites, quantification of climatic impacts on observed nonstationarity in flood series, and evaluation of the sensitivity of flood statistics to a variety of measurable basin characteristics. Our results indicate a strong association between annual maximum flood magnitude and associated precipitation series, as well as the timing of flood peaks and associated temperature series. Strong relationships were observed between flood magnitude and anomalies of both the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation. Relatively weaker teleconnections were observed in response to the El Nino Southern Oscillation and the North Atlantic Oscillation. In comparing results across the unimpaired and moderately impaired watersheds, results suggest that influences of meteorological variables on flows are attenuated by human activities within the watershed. Thus, it is important to quantify the relative impact of human activities versus meteorological variables on flood behavior in order to adequately project future flood risk under scenarios of changing climate and land use. To this end, twelve representative watersheds were selected for more detailed analysis.

A physical hydrologic model was developed for each case study watershed and subsequently used to assess the impacts of historical land use/land cover (LULC) on flood distributions, and to evaluate impacts of future LULC/climate scenarios on resultant flood risk projections. Results suggest that larger shifts in flood distributions are anticipated in more urban watersheds, than for those that are presently dominated by agricultural land use, and larger impacts are projected in the lower tail of the flood distribution. These physically based findings corroborate the results of statistical analyses, which suggest that streamflows are increasing in terms of annual and seasonal minimums and medians, i.e. the US is getting wetter, but not necessarily more extreme.

In developing the physical hydrologic models, of particular interest was to identify which calibration parameters had the most influence on projected flood risk, and how well a model calibrated for one period (set of LULC and climate conditions) worked under altered conditions. The models of the case study watersheds were calibrated and validated based on observed data spanning 2000-2009, then employed to simulate streamflows for 1970-1999 and derive the resultant flood series. The characteristics of the simulated flood series were compared against those of the observed flood series for the same period. The impact of calibration on the simulated flood risk distribution for each case study watershed was investigated by perturbing each parameter over a reasonable range of values. Our results suggest adjusting calibration parameters in proportion to the observed changes in land use/land cover and/or climate in order to improve simulation of the flood distribution for the projection period. For example, in watersheds that experience temperature changes between the calibration and projection periods, results suggest that variables associated with temperature (e.g. snow parameters) need to be adjusted in proportion to the observed change in temperature. Doing so significantly improved simulations of the flood risk distribution, even under altered LULC conditions.

Impacts for other disciplines stem from the demonstration that shifts in the low to median quantiles of the flood distribution are anticipated with land use/land cover change (most significantly with increased urbanization, but perhaps as well with shifts in agricultural practices or crop rotation), but not for the larger quantiles. It has been suggested that more extreme rain events would lead to increased loading, presumably due to increased flows in the upper tails of the distribution; however, our work indicates that changes should be anticipated in response to smaller storm events leading to increased proportions of runoff, and thus also perhaps increased non-point source pollution. Of course, the timing of storm events relative to activities such as fertilizer application would play a role, but this work could inform related simulations of future water quality and ecological conditions. Especially if adjustments of the calibrated hydrologic model are made in proportion to the observed (projected) changes in temperature, such that the hydrologic model better represents the flow distribution anticipated for the projection period.
